results.title: For France, American Vines Still Mean Sour Grapes
results.abstract: French authorities have tried to outlaw hardy American hybrids for 87 years. But climate change and the natural wine movement are giving renegade winemakers a lift.

multimedia.caption: A tasting of forbidden wines at Hervé Garnier’s “Memory of the Vine” association in the village of Beaumont. Mr. Garnier, standing third from right, is one of the last stragglers in a long-running struggle against the French wine establishment and its allies in Paris.
multimedia.copyright: Andrea Mantovani for The New York Times

results.title: ‘What Will Happen to Me?’ An Uncertain Future Awaits Afghans Who Fled
results.abstract: Tens of thousands clambered onto evacuation planes bound for Qatar. Many are now in limbo in overflowing processing centers, fearful of what comes next.
results.byline: By Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

multimedia.caption: In this photograph released by the U.S. Central Command, American soldiers prepared to let evacuees on a plane at an air base in Qatar. Military regulations prevented independent news photography at the base.

results.title: As the Taliban Tighten Their Grip, Fears of Retribution Grow
results.abstract: Taliban leaders have promised amnesty to Afghan officials and soldiers, but there are increasing reports of detentions, disappearances and even executions.
des_facet: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

results.title: Britons, Unfazed by High Covid Rates, Weigh Their ‘Price of Freedom’
results.abstract: Britain is reporting more than 30,000 new coronavirus cases a day, but the public seems to have moved on. Experts say this could be a glimpse into the future for other countries.
results.byline: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle

multimedia.caption: Concertgoers on Friday at the Reading Music Festival in Reading, England. “We don’t seem to care that we have these really high infection rates,” said Tim Spector, a professor of genetic epidemiology at King’s College London.

results.title: After Airport Bombing, an Afghan Family Buries a Father, and Hope

results.title: Giant Puppet Ruffles Some Feathers on a Long Walk Through Greece
results.abstract: “Little Amal” is on a 5,000-mile journey from Turkey to Britain to highlight the plight of Syrian refugees. But in Greece, some have objected to her presence, saying it could encourage more migrants.
results.byline: By Niki Kitsantonis and Alex Marshall
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

multimedia.caption: “Little Amal” last month in Gaziantep, Turkey, at the start of her 5,000-mile journey. She “walks” with the help of a team of puppeteers.

results.title: How Rodrigo Duterte Can Stay No. 1 by Becoming No. 2

results.title: Italy will impose tighter restrictions in Sicily after a surge in cases.
results.abstract: A majority of hospitalizations on the southern island have involved the unvaccinated, and many have yet to get shots.

results.title: Afghanistan Collapse and Strikes in Somalia Raise Snags for Drone Warfare Rules
results.abstract: But the Biden administration is close to finishing a new playbook for counterterrorism strikes outside conventional war zones.
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

results.title: The U.S. retaliates over the airport bombing, days before the withdrawal deadline.
results.abstract: The U.S. military said that it had killed its target in the first strike since a deadly attack on the Kabul airport.
results.byline: By Daniel Victor, Eric Schmitt, Zia ur-Rehman, Jim Huylebroek, Najim Rahim and Matthieu Aikins

results.title: How Canadian Leaders Campaign in a Pandemic

results.title: Texas anti-mask organizer clings to life in a battle with Covid-19.
results.abstract: Caleb Wallace, a leader in the anti-mask movement in San Angelo, Texas, is in an intensive care unit and his wife says his condition is life-threatening.

results.title: U.S. Launches Strike on ISIS-K as Bombing’s Death Toll Soars
results.abstract: The Pentagon said its drone strike appeared to have killed a planner for the terror group, which claimed responsibility for the blast at Kabul’s airport that left more than 170 dead.
results.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Eric Schmitt
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
